articles.headline: In Departure, China Invites Outside Help
articles.snippet: China sought experts and equipment from Japan and Taiwan as President Hu Jintao visited the area affected by the earthquake.
articles.abstract: China sought experts and equipment from Japan and Taiwan as President Hu Jintao visited the area affected by the earthquake.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIANYANG, China  With the death toll from this week’s earthquake rising rapidly, China has departed from past diplomatic practice, seeking disaster relief experts and heavy equipment needed for rescue operations from neighbors it has long shunned as rivals or renegades.
articles.byline: By Howard W. French and Edward Wong

articles.headline: Color-Blind Merrill in a Sea of Red Flags
articles.snippet: So-called piggyback loans have been highly vulnerable to homeowners who walk away when property values fall.
articles.abstract: So-called piggyback loans have been highly vulnerable to homeowners who walk away when property values fall.
articles.lead_paragraph: Would you invest money  at a very low interest rate  to finance mortgage loans made to risky borrowers who put no money down? What if you knew the company that made most of the loans had gone bankrupt because so many of its loans had turned bad almost immediately?

articles.headline: Investigator to the Stars Is Convicted in Wiretaps
articles.snippet: Anthony Pellicano was a ripped-from-a-pulp-novel private eye who made himself an indispensable Hollywood fixer.
articles.abstract: Anthony Pellicano was a ripped-from-a-pulp-novel private eye who made himself an indispensable Hollywood fixer.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Anthony Pellicano, the ripped-from-a-pulp-novel private eye who made himself an indispensable fixer for Hollywood stars and moguls, was found guilty in federal court Thursday of racketeering, wiretapping and other charges.

articles.headline: CBS in Deal to Buy CNet to Increase Online Ads
articles.snippet: At $1.8 billion, Thursday’s deal for CNet by CBS is the biggest by far in its recent Internet expansion, making the network a bigger player in online media.
articles.abstract: At $1.8 billion, Thursday’s deal for CNet by CBS is the biggest by far in its recent Internet expansion, making the network a bigger player in online media.
articles.lead_paragraph: Networks typically trot out corporate executives, programmers and stars to pitch to advertisers during the television industry’s annual upfront season.

articles.headline: Germany Debates Subsidies for Solar Industry
articles.snippet: Thanks to its aggressive push into renewable energies, cloud-wreathed Germany has become an unlikely leader in the race to harness the sun’s energy.
articles.abstract: Thanks to its aggressive push into renewable energies, cloud-wreathed Germany has become an unlikely leader in the race to harness the sun’s energy.
articles.lead_paragraph: THALHEIM, Germany  This sad stretch of eastern Germany, with its deserted coal mines and corroded factories, epitomizes post-industrial gloom. It is a place where even the clouds rarely seem to part.

articles.headline: Bush Speech Criticized as Attack on Obama
articles.snippet: President Bush said in a speech in Israel that talking to “terrorists and radicals” was a form of appeasement.
articles.abstract: President Bush said in a speech in Israel that talking to “terrorists and radicals” was a form of appeasement.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — President Bush used a speech to the Israeli Parliament on Thursday to denounce those who would negotiate with “terrorists and radicals” — a remark that was widely interpreted as a rebuke to Senator Barack Obama, the Democratic presidential contender, who has argued that the United States should talk directly with countries like Iran and Syria.

articles.headline: California Supreme Court Overturns Gay Marriage Ban
articles.snippet: The ruling, striking down laws limiting marriages to unions between a man and a woman, would make California the second state to allow same-sex marriage.
articles.abstract: The ruling, striking down laws limiting marriages to unions between a man and a woman, would make California the second state to allow same-sex marriage.
articles.lead_paragraph: The California Supreme Court, striking down two state laws that had limited marriages to unions between a man and a woman, ruled on Thursday that same-sex couples have a constitutional right to marry.

articles.headline: Zimbabwe’s Rulers Unleash Police on Anglicans
articles.snippet: Ahead of a presidential runoff, the ruling party is focusing an intimidation campaign on groups it does not control.
articles.abstract: Ahead of a presidential runoff, the ruling party is focusing an intimidation campaign on groups it does not control.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG  The parishioners were lined up for Holy Communion on Sunday when the riot police stormed the stately St. Francis Anglican Church in Harare, Zimbabwe’s capital. Helmeted, black-booted officers banged on the pews with their batons as terrified members of the congregation stampeded for the doors, witnesses said.

articles.headline: McCain Vision Has Most G.I.’s Out of Iraq by 2013
articles.snippet: John McCain’s comments were a striking departure from his usual refusal to set a date for American withdrawal.
articles.abstract: John McCain’s comments were a striking departure from his usual refusal to set a date for American withdrawal.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Senator John McCain declared on Thursday that most American troops would be home from Iraq by 2013 and that the nation would be a functioning democracy with only “spasmodic” episodes of violence. The comments were a striking departure from his usual refusal to set a date for American withdrawal.

articles.headline: For Wall Street Workers, Ax Falls Quietly
articles.snippet: Some people who have lost jobs, and many more struggling to hold them, say banks are keeping employees in the dark about the size and timing of layoffs.
articles.abstract: Some people who have lost jobs, and many more struggling to hold them, say banks are keeping employees in the dark about the size and timing of layoffs.
articles.lead_paragraph: People on Wall Street seem to be vanishing overnight.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Bush Assails ‘Appeasement,’ Touching Off Storm
articles.snippet: A remark seen as a rebuke to Barack Obama likened those who would negotiate with “terrorists” to Nazi appeasers.
articles.abstract: A remark seen as a rebuke to Barack Obama likened those who would negotiate with “terrorists” to Nazi appeasers.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM  President Bush used a speech to the Israeli Parliament on Thursday to liken those who would negotiate with “terrorists and radicals” to appeasers of the Nazis  a remark widely interpreted as a rebuke to Senator Barack Obama, who has advocated greater engagement with countries like Iran and Syria.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Jim Rutenberg
